Title: the locomotion reverberation

Scene: some great stuff out here. Oh, this is good. There are dozens of railroad crossings you have to blow the whistle for. But that is the figurative you, not the literal you. I’ll be blowing the whistle. Amy, get up. It’s time to go to work.
The cab of a steam locomotive.
Howard: Okay, I’m zeroing out the electro-osmotic flow rate in the micro-fluidic channel.
Well, my wife is four-foot-ten and sexually satisfied, so clearly I know my way around tiny things.
Those are just the things I say out loud.
What’s wrong?
Yeah. It doesn’t need to be smaller.
Sheldon, we don’t need to make this smaller, and your work is done. Go home.
I know. That’s why I keep refilling his water when he’s not looking.
I don’t care if we’re in a drought, it’s worth it.
We can just lock the door, you don’t have to kill him.
It’s so peaceful without him here. Can I ask you how much that cost?
Great. We found a cooling solution that allowed us to get the size of the prototype down to the target specs.
But we’ve already met the agreed upon specs. Going smaller would require weeks’ worth of new computations.
Okay, but that’s just a theory. It’s not even a complete thought.
The kid with the two shirts screwed us again.
I can’t believe we have to ask Sheldon to come back and help us.
I don’t know, but if he yells It’s alive, we run.
How’d you even get that up the stairs?
Open a window. It’s about to get smug in here.
He’s worried about looking foolish. That’s a heapin’ helping of irony right there.
All right. Hmm. Feel free to jump in. Hmm is all I got.
Maybe we can find another theoretical physicist to help us.
Hey, I came up with that and hmm. You haven’t pitched anything.
You really figured it out?
Oh, you’re a genius.
That’s right. We figured it out all by ourselves. Wasn’t even that hard.
It’s a manifold.
Told ya. Can you fix it for us?
But if you really want to learn the mechanical side, I can teach you anything you want to know.
And with all these new skills, you’d be able to fix any model train. You’d be the king of the train store.
That’s a turbo.
Leonard: Nicely done, Howard.
Good for you, on the cutting edge of new technology and still making inappropriate comments about the mother of your child.
That’s great, but the Air Force approved the specs. We’re good to go.
Can we please stop talking about poodles?
Fine, go for a little walk.
Just keep walking.
At least it’s quiet when he takes bathroom breaks.
You’re kidding.
You know, I do have a way to get him out of our hair. I’ve been holding onto this for a few years, but maybe now’s the time.
You can’t kill him, he’ll just respawn at the last save point.
Hey, uh, buddy, I got you a little present.
Yeah. Go ahead, open it.
Okay. Where were we?
This train thing worked out better than I thought. He’s home studying the engineer’s manual.
Four thousand dollars, worth every penny.
Colonel Williams. Sir.
As a cooling solution, it’s pretty cool.
Oh, nothing. Just some math we don’t need.
It’s just a theory. Uh, it’s not even worked out.
Sir, uh, if I may, uh, we’ve put a lot of thought and effort into this current prototype. It’s a really elegant solution, and most importantly, it works.
Oh, boo-hoo. I spent four grand on a gift that only got rid of him for an afternoon. What is that?
Okay, look, Sheldon, the Colonel wants us to make the guidance system smaller, and we can’t do it without you.
Sheldon, you can still go on the trip in a few weeks. Just help us out.
Come on, you know you’re not leaving physics. Why are you doing this?
Okay. This is everything he had on the board. I’m sure we can figure the rest out.
Oh, we can get this. Is there any chance it’s upside-down?
It’s classified. If we tell anyone, we’d get in trouble.
Just keep thinking. I got it.
No, but when we show this nonsense to Sheldon, it will make him crazy, and he’ll have to fix it.
Yeah, I know. That’s not even a math symbol. That’s just Charlie Brown’s hair.
Well, Sheldon, turns out we didn’t need you after all.
No.
Aren’t you gonna look at the board to see how right we are?
Just look at the board.
Oh, no, what should we have done differently?
Come on, Sheldon. You can’t turn your back on physics, and besides, you have no idea what you’re doing with this stuff.
And instead of standing around watching, you can help us build your smaller guidance system.
So, what do you say?
Sheldon: Gentlemen, we need to stop immediately.
I’m looking at the math, and I think we can make the device between eight and ten percent smaller.

Shame on you. Where would we be if poodle breeders had that attitude? I’ll tell you. We would have the standard and the miniature poodle, but no toy or teacup. Which by the way, is not an officially recognized breed, but that’s just poodle politics.
Fine. Candy bars. Now, do you enjoy a fun size? I know you do.
I don’t want to go home.
Then what?
Oh, that was my sixth trip to the bathroom. As long as that’s not a urinary tract infection, that’s a personal best.
Really?

Congratulations. The bearer of this certificate is entitled to the ultimate train experience at The Nevada Northern Railway. You are at the throttle. You are the engineer. You are running the locomotive. This doesn’t happen very often, but here comes a hug. Oh, dear, I have to tinkle again.
You’ll never believe it. Leonard gave me the most incredible gift, a trip to a historic railway, and I get to operate an actual locomotive.
No idea. All I know is I’m gonna be working on the railroad all the livelong day.
Oh, no. It’s not just me. No. The railway is four hours from the nearest airport, and guess who gets to drive me.
You.

Oh, oh. And guess where we get to sleep? Our choice of a turn-of-the-century railway bunkhouse or a working caboose. Now, the problem with a caboose is there’s no bathroom, but the problem with the bunkhouse is it’s not a caboose. On the first day, I get to drive a steam engine. Oh, and the second day, a diesel engine. Oh, and if I volunteer to do track maintenance and paperwork, they’ll let me stay as long as I want. So you might want to pack enough clothes for the rest of our lives.
Oh, get this. I get to take a test based on a 125-page manual. I get to learn things like hand signals. Ooh. There’s forward, uh, reverse, set the brakes. Are you done yet? You’re missing
Oh, hey. If you knocked, I couldn’t hear you. I’m welding this locomotive engine. And if you didn’t knock, how about some manners?
I said to myself, I think I can, I think I can. And then I couldn’t, so I paid two men who promised not to come rob us later.
Interesting. Well, so I was right.

Well, I would love to help you, but since I discovered the satisfaction of working with my hands on a train engine, I don’t think I can go back to theory. I’m an engineer now. And, hey, just to be clear, a train engineer. Not that goofy kind you are.
Sorry. I need to work on this engine so when I get to the train yard I won’t look foolish.

Leonard, in the world of theoretical physics, you never finish. So much is unprovable. But when I was studying that railway guide, it was so tangible and so satisfying that something just clicked. Then it clacked. Then it clicked, then it clacked, click-clack clickety-clack, and here we are. Whoo-whoo.
Well, good for you guys. Look, I have a grease smudge on my hand, and I’m okay with it.
No, thanks. I’m busy trying to fix this fuel pump.
Oh. Well, I guess it’s fixed.
That’s wrong.
Well, first of all, you can’t use relativistic and non-relativistic vectors in the same equation.
Okay, but this is the last time. Nice try, blockheads.
Excuse me. I have a girlfriend. I’m already king of the train store.
Oh, what choice do I have? You need me. I’m like the crankshaft of this team.
Well, whatever it is, it looks heavy. I’m gonna need you two to get it downstairs before Amy comes home.
I apologize that it’s so warm in here.
I’ve worked up a bit of a sweat.
May I borrow your water?
GPS says we’ll be at the railway in three hours.
Bernadette: For Howie’s occupation, should I include that he was an astronaut?
Well, I didn’t. I also skipped a birthing class to see Zootopia so back off.
Sorry. Howie’s back at work and there’s just so much going on.
Sure. Open up a college fund, shop for life insurance, and in the laundry room, there’s a mountain of dirty laundry. Wash it or burn in, your choice. Ugh, be right back.
Oh, thank you.
That sounds really nice.
We will. Got my dancing shoes, got my breast pump. Let’s party.
Call if there’s any problems.
Call me. Don’t call Howard.
Not yet, but we’re gonna apply to a bunch of others just to keep our options open.
Raj, what’s going on?
I’m sure it’s fine, but if you’re worried, there’s extra milk in the freezer.
Stuart, don’t you drink my milk.
You guys got this? Do you need me to come home?
Yeah. I may have just left my infant daughter with Patrick and SpongeBob.
Yeah, we’re all dressed up. Why go home?
What’s going on with you?
I’m not sad. I just wanted to get drunk and not wear sweatpants.
You’re upset I had a baby?
You think that stuff is fun? Being a parent is terrifying. I’m constantly worried, I’m always tired, and in a few minutes I’m gonna milk myself in a bookstore parking lot.
You may not have a house yet, but your apartment’s great.
And Leonard loves you so much, he married you twice.
Careful. The sound of crying can make me lactate.
And there they go.
Amy: Well, he mentioned it in his mother’s eulogy, so why not?
Is there anything we can do?
Oh. All this week, the Early Music Society of Pasadena is doing a joint concert with the San Gabriel Renaissance Choir.
Good luck. People have been saying that for 600 years.
Hey, you’re home early.
Wow. He finally used it. What’d you do?
Well, I’m really happy for you.
I give up.
No. I really give up.
Can I pee now?
Well, the bra under here ain’t beige.
Hey, did you hear anything back from the Caltech preschool?
Nothing says fun like being scolded.
Renaissance Choir’s looking pretty good right now, huh?
Hey, there’s another dance club nearby. I mean, I don’t know how you feel about Latin music, but according to their horas of operación, they’re open.
You sure? They’re open till dos.
I’m not sad. I mean, hello.
What are you sad about?
What feelings?
Come on. You’ve got so much to feel good about. You’ve got a great job now.
You make more than I do.
It’s bigger than mine.
I’m not even engaged once. I don’t even know if Sheldon thinks about marriage. I’m not getting any younger. Honestly, I kind of thought by now, we might have had some sort of…
I’m sorry. I can’t help it.
It is warm in here.
Me, too.
I can get us there in two.
Penny: I can’t believe you have to fill out a preschool application for an infant.

All right, you know what you need? A night away from all of this. You know, where you can just kind of relax and, I’m just gonna turn this off. Much better. Seriously, let’s plan a night, you know, give you a break. We could go dancing.
Okay, that’s the one to beat.
All right. You guys ready to get crazy?
You know, if you pump at the bar, I promise we’ll get free drinks.
No. She’s busy. You call Howard.
Okay, stop that. No more preschool talk. Tonight is about having fun.
Okay, give. Can you guys handle this or not?
Sorry, guys. This club was so great, how could they turn it into a bookstore? I thought we got rid of all those.
Is everything okay?
Maybe we should just call it a night.
I’m just not really in the mood anymore.
I don’t know. This is all starting to feel like a sad attempt to recapture our youth.
Okay, maybe I’m the one who’s sad.
Maybe the fact that you went and had a baby.
No, of course not. I just, I didn’t think it would make me have all these feelings.
Pressure. I mean, she’s looking at preschools, she has a minivan, she has a 401K. Before she talked about it, I just thought that was a race.
I get that, okay? It’s just, Leonard and I have been married for two years, and we’re no further along than when we were dating.
Yeah, I guess I am making decent money.
Oh, that’s gonna make me cry.
Ew.
Raj: Uh, the one at Caltech has a crazy wait list. I warned you, a lot of people apply when they’re still pregnant.
Whoa. Just trying to help.
No, no. I will take care of it.
While I’m gone, you can think about how mean you were to me.
Okay. You ladies have fun tonight.
Under the careful supervision of her godfather.
Like I said, you ladies have fun.
Got it.
I would never call Howard.
Yeah, great. Um, I’ll put food in her top half, you deal with whatever comes out the bottom.
Don’t worry. Everything’s fine.
I don’t need your help deciding when we need help!
Yes, so, I was just warming up some milk for Halley, and I thought it smelled a little funky, so I checked the date that you wrote on the bottle, and it says Flerbsday.
How is that a T?
Okay, yes, I will err on the side of caution and defrost a fresh batch.
Fine, you drink it.
Oh, of course we can. Uh, you girls have a good time. She said I was in charge.
What else are you gonna do with it? Put it in your coffee?
Nothing to worry about. She’s just been crying for a little while, and I was wondering if you had any tricks to get her to sleep.
She was blowing a spit bubble. It was adorable.
Oh, okay, false alarm. Little parenting tip, sleeping babies hate flash photography.
Col Williams: Just wanted to see how the guidance system’s coming along.
This is a different approach. Are you trying to get the guidance system even smaller?
So get the kid with the two shirts to do it.
You both make excellent points, and thank you for presenting it so articulately. Make this.
Stuart: Don’t worry about Halley. Uncle Stuart’s on the job.
My apologies. I didn’t mean to offend you, Don Corleone.
Okay, instead of arguing all night, let’s just split up the baby chores.
Hang up, we don’t need help.
Hmm. So we just throw this away?
Well, I don’t take it black.
She was sleeping just fine till you took a selfie with her.
